awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Behavioral flexibility and space use in nonhuman primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Behavioral flexibility, or the ability to change one’s behavior in different contexts, is a key human trait, but how this trait emerged in our lineage is less understood. Research shows that non-human primates show more behavioral flexibility than previously assumed. One way to approach the question of the emergence and nature of human behavioral flexibility is through a comparative study of how spaces are used, as representations of the range of behavioral decisions shown among our close nonhuman primate relatives. In particular, understanding the capability of different primates to modify their behavior in response to the fluctuating availability of food resources or changes in social relationships has the potential to provide valuable insights into promotes behavioral variation among primates, the importance of such variability in human evolution, and the behavioral capabilities of our human ancestors. This doctoral dissertation research project examines space use strategies of wild groups of a close human relative, to investigate how natural variation in food availability and changes in social dynamics can explain differences in space use. This project contributes to the training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as primate conservation.

This study uses home range specific resource availability collected across the home ranges of five nonhuman primate groups, all occurrences of interactions between them, and daily follows of focal individuals to document initiations of group movements within their home ranges. These data are used to address three main questions: what differences in home range specific resource access promotes variation in space use strategies, whether differences in ranging overlap is linked to differences in social relationships between groups, and whether differences in group size and leadership influence group movement decisions. In addition to addressing the growing demand for investigations into behavioral variation from both anthropology and cognitive sciences, this research implements new technological approaches in data collection and analyses. A combination of spatially explicit resource modelling, social network analyses, and group-level comparisons are used to evaluate flexibility in primate space use strategies. This research not only addresses long-standing questions on the evolution of behavioral variation but can also be used to inform conservation strategies aimed at protecting non-human primates across the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Variation and flexibility are a hallmark of human behavior. Although most biological anthropologists would agree that behavioral variation is prevalent throughout primates, very few non-human primates have datasets large enough to investigate species and population-level behavioral diversity. Correspondingly, the evolutionary driver behind human uniqueness in behavioral diversity is unclear in part because of an inability to compare behavioral diversity and flexibility across primates. Investigation into primate behavioral variability and flexibility, particularly in our closest living relatives, the apes, could provide comparisons to better evaluate our species unique behavioral diversity.

This study investigated whether western lowland gorillas in the Ndoki Forest of Republic of Congo demonstrate differences in space use strategies across groups, and what ecological and social factors may facilitate such differences. Specifically, we set out to see if groups differed in their access to food resources, if group home range use differed with presence of other groups, and if groups differed in how they made space use decisions. Western lowland gorilla groups in this study had similar access to food resources, although differences in resource consumption were prevalent. Similarly, we found that although all groups demonstrated similar avoidances of other groups throughout their range, different groups were more likely to be in the same region at the same time than other groups, potentially indicating preferred neighbors. Lastly, we found that group travel decisions were variable both within and across groups based on spatial context and measures of success, however silverbacks demonstrated a disproportionate influence on travel decisions across most groups. These results indicate a high degree of populational variation in western lowland gorilla space use strategies, with both ecological and social factors corresponding to group level differences in space use.

This research expands our knowledge of western lowland gorilla socioecology, with data collected from two field sites that have conducted research on western lowland gorillas for over twenty years. This investigation incorporates data from multiple, neighboring habituated western lowland gorilla groups, enhancing our understanding of their ecology, social behavior, and behavioral flexibility. Data collection applied focal follows, providing exhaustive behavioral information from which further research on western lowland gorilla behavior and cognition can be explored. Throughout their fieldwork, the Co-PI worked alongside Congolese research assistants, research staff, and graduate students, assisting with professional development and conservation project creation and mentorship. The Co-PI created a standardized great ape home range analysis manual provided to research staff and conservation partners, which will facilitate standardized comparisons of western lowland gorilla across collaborative projects throughout the region. Similarly, the Co-PI worked with in country gorilla habituation experts to combine best practice habituation methods with measurable habituation benchmarks for future country-wide gorilla habituation goals, both for research and eco-tourism.

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2024
Modified by: Kathryn N Judson
